reasoning: The critique targets the essay’s “value-as-product-of-factors”/fragility illustration, which is a meaningful support for the ‘no easy eutopia’ conclusion but not the core of the overall case (which also relies on historical moral catastrophe analogies and an extended argument that many plausible moral views are intrinsically ‘fussy’). So centrality is moderate-low. It has some bite: strong positive correlations between moral progress dimensions would make the independence-based multiplicative story less pessimistic about how rarely many things go right together. However, it doesn’t show that correlations are strong enough, robust across key dimensions, or net-positive (some could be negative, or dominated by lock-in/power dynamics), and it overstates the paper as “calculating probability as the product” rather than using independence as a toy model/intuition pump. Thus it only modestly weakens the attacked component. The critique is mostly coherent and plausible in spirit (correlation/‘expanding circle’ considerations are real), but partially mischaracterizes how central/committed the authors are to strict independence, lowering correctness somewhat.
title: Correlated moral and technological progress undermines the independence assumption
